explanation:
- OS_impl_binsem_internal_record_t: needed to see the definition of the sem object (members cv and id) and whether those members are declared as const or non-const. This determines whether a pointer-to-const could be used.
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: the macro expansion/definition is required to know the exact return type and const-qualification of the pointer produced by the lookup (i.e., whether it yields a const or non-const pointer to the record).
- OS_impl_bin_sem_table: the table symbol and its type feed into OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET expansion; its type/constness can affect the resulting pointer type.
- OS_object_token_t: required to confirm the semantics of *token (how the token is used by the table-get) and whether token indirection affects const-correctness of the returned pointer.
- pthread_cond_destroy: prototype/signature is needed to confirm whether it requires a pointer to a modifiable pthread_cond_t (i.e., non-const parameter). If the API requires non-const, the sem pointer cannot be const when used to take &sem->cv.
- pthread_mutex_destroy: same as above for pthread_mutex_t: its prototype tells whether the mutex parameter must be non-const, which prevents making sem a pointer-to-const.
- pthread_cond_t and pthread_mutex_t: the underlying types of sem->cv and sem->id are needed to determine if those members themselves are const-qualified or mutable types; together with the destroy prototypes this decides whether a const-qualified pointer would be permissible.

(These symbols provide the type and API information necessary to decide if any pointer in the function could or should be const-qualified without breaking the calls to pthread_cond_destroy/pthread_mutex_destroy or mismatching the table-get return type.)
